DOC.HEAD: Families of Passengers Hold Service
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of the passengers who died in the crash of Pan American Flight 103 gathered to support one another in a season of painful reminders. ``I don't think for any of us Christmas will ever be the same,'' said Bert Ammerman, whose brother, Thomas, died on the flight. Ammerman, of nearby River Vale, is the head of one group of relatives, The Victims of Pan Am Flight 103. Surrounded by Christmas wreaths, Advent candles and a manger, members of 22 families of the victims attended a service Sunday at the Ramsey Presbyterian Church. The first anniversary of the crash is Thursday. On Dec. 21, 1988, a bomb blew the the Boeing 747 apart, killing 259 passengers and crew. Another 11 people died on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. Joan Dater, a member of the northern New Jersey congregation whose daughter, Gretchen, died in the bombing, said she and her family planned to spend Christmas together. ``It's painful because Gretchen won't be there, of course, but Gretchen loved Christmas,'' Mrs. Dater said. She called the service a ``gift from the church.'' The Rev. Robert A. Colman, minister at Ramsey First Presbyterian, said the congregation wanted to mark the anniversary of the bombing and discussed it with the Daters. ``We wanted to keep it simple,'' he said. ``Blessed are those who mourn, for you shall be comforted,'' Colman told the congregation of about 70, which included the family of a former church elder, James Fuller, who died on the flight. Colman urged the families to grieve and remember their relatives. The family of college student Alexia Tsairis has established a foundation in her memory to promote conflict resolution. Her father, Peter Tsairis, said the family was talking with Syracuse University, where she studied, to establish such a program. ``We need to stop terrorism, and the way to do that is through education,'' he said. Peter Lowenstein, whose son Alexander died on the flight, said he questioned why there were 168 empty seats on flight 103. He said there was evidence some passengers had canceled their reservations at the last minute and called for somebody to ``come forward and tell us that actually occurred.'' Ammerman said some relatives of the victims planned to attend a public memorial service set for Thursday in Washington, while others plan to go into seclusion. Mrs. Dater said another service was planned in Ramsey on Thursday at the John Y. Dater Elementary school, named after Gretchen Dater's great-grandfather. At 2:02 p.m., church bells in the community will ring for 270 seconds, she said. ``It's going to be a very difficult week,'' Ammerman said.
